posts.name: Andrew Bernard
posts.cooked:
Suddenly, from my colleague, files to download come with temp names like signal-2025-06-20-232142 instead ot the filename as they always used to. We have tried everything.

What has changed and gone wrong?

Version 7.58.0
As far as I know that has always been the behavior. Signal doesn’t preserve the original filename and gives it a generic name with the timestamp, presumably for privacy reasons.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked: yeah, i also remember that as always being the behaviour. in fact i can confirm i have files older than v7.58 with that naming scheme.

posts.name: Andrew Bernard
posts.cooked: Well all I can say is that for a very long time since I ever installed Signal having a chat in which the B party adds a TIFF file results in my being able to download it with its filename. Furthermore, the same for a PDF, which still works. So my experience is apparently at odds with the reality. This makes no sense to me. Platform is Windows 11 Pro, with latest updates. I have no reason to be making this up - I’d just like to revert to the ‘normal’ behavior. But if this cannot be addressed then I’ll just uninstall Signal and give up - but that does not seem right.
If i remember correct i wondered about when i got files with original filename in th meantime. Not sure but i think it were images. Maybe it was a oversight in a previous version.

posts.name: Andrew Bernard
posts.cooked:
This is most certainly a change that has occurred. I went back to 31 May and files download just fine.

How do I submit a bug report?

andro:

I have no reason to be making this up - I’d just like to revert to the ‘normal’ behavior

Maybe there was a bug that caused certain files to not have their file names changed, but “normal” behavior for Signal is to give downloaded files a name using the timestamp.

posts.name: Michel
posts.cooked:
There has been some change on filenames in 7.58, not sure if that’s related, this is the commit:

github.com/signalapp/Signal-Desktop

Strip filenames for visual media attachments during upload

committed 06:14PM - 09 Jun 25 UTC
automated-signal
+11 -6

Co-authored-by: yash-signal <yash@signal.org>

But I agree with the others, I also always had the timestamp format for filenames. Maybe this commit fixed some bug on that part

link_counts.title: Strip filenames for visual media attachments during upload · signalapp/Signal-Desktop@8ef0f0a · GitHub

posts.name: Andrew Bernard
posts.cooked: It’s strange to me that having the right and full filename is a ‘bug’. 'Fixing; this renders Signal far less useable for me, as I principally use it for collaborative work on music scores, with intensive forward and backward file exchage. I will have to find another way.

Contributor:

not sure if that’s related

Yep, it definitely is, for images and videos anyway:

 // Strip filename for visual media (images and videos) to prevent metadata leakage

That has been the behavior in the mobile client as long as I know, so maybe it has just been missing from the desktop client, or they unintentionally stopped doing that when rewriting part of the desktop code.

andro:

I principally use it for collaborative work on music scores, with intensive forward and backward file exchage. I will have to find another way.

That sounds like something more fit for a file sharing platform rather than a messaging app. If you want something with high security and privacy, Proton Drive would be a good option.

However, you should still be able to continue using Signal if you put your files in an archive file first (zip, rar, tar, etc)

Before placing into an archive container, you could try simply giving the file a different extension, so that the client doesn’t treat it as a media file.

Though I agree with @andro and would prefer that my files and file-associated metadata were left intact. There are other means to remove metadata as well as change filenames. If the file needs to be attached to the Signal chat anyway, then it was already in some other (likely less secure) storage. I am fine with Signal having generic names and minimal metadata for media that is generated within the Signal client.

CueHD:

If the file needs to be attached to the Signal chat anyway, then it was already in some other (likely less secure) storage

It’s about the destination, not the origin. Signal strips metadata from images so that you don’t accidentally reveal things to your recipients that you didn’t intend to. Filenames can contain sensitive information, so they remove those as well. It makes it easier to send things quickly without having to remember that you need to go and rename a bunch of files first.

Herohtar:

Signal strips metadata from images so that you don’t accidentally reveal things to your recipients that you didn’t intend to.

I do not require Signal to think for me and determine what I intend to do.

Also, since the often stated paradigm is that Signal is for communicating with people whom one trusts, this behavior is not consistent.

Herohtar:

It makes it easier to send things quickly without having to remember that you need to go and rename a bunch of files first.

This wouldn’t be an issue (for me at least) if I could select to have information retained. As it is now, there is no option for me to remember to go and activate metadata or put the filename back before sending. I can accept that the default behavior may be different from my preference, but the choice is removed from the user. If Signal did nothing in this regard, the choice would still be there if renaming the file were desired.

There seem to be conflicting behaviours here for different users. In all my clients it has always been the case that signal strips filenames for images and video but never for other filetypes (e.g. PDFs or ZIPs).

I’m on Linux and several android versions and this happens in all those places reproducibly. It is in line with what the “media” section shows as well, no names for images, videos and audio, but definitely for anything that appears in the “files” tab.
I haven’t tested it yet, but that is what I recall also. @andro specically mentioned a TIFF which might have previously been treated as a regular file, but is now being renamed as an image.
Yes, I thought so that too, especially since there was a commit mentioned pertaining to the treatment of images, so the included formats may have changed.
